name: Queen Elizabeth Park
homepage_content: Greater Wellington ‚Äî Queen Elizabeth Park Queen Elizabeth Park | Greater Wellington Queen Elizabeth Park Haere mai, welcome to Queen Elizabeth Park location_on Location Located between PaekƒÅkƒÅriki and Raumati South, KƒÅpiti Coast This is one of our most popular parks - a great place for a day out with family and friends on the KƒÅpiti Coast. Opening hours Parks are always open to foot traffic. Vehicle gates are open 6am-6pm 1 April ‚Äì 30 Sept, and 6am-9pm 1 Oct ‚Äì 31 Mar. info_outline Notices Activities Walking and hiking Mountain biking and cycling Dog walking Horse riding Model aeroplane flying Volunteering History US Marines history Learn more > open_in_new See more Activities add Walking and hiking Queen Elizabeth Park has a variety of different trails and most are suitable for pushchairs and wheelchairs. Each track offers a different experience - around wetlands, through dunes, amongst kahikatea forest remnants, across paddocks, or beside the coast and passing historical landmarks. Most tracks are shared with either cyclists, horses, or both, so be aware and take care. Queen Elizabeth Park trail map Read more here date_range Published 15 Jul 2022 Download now (PDF 753 KB) get_app Track Time / grade Details Whareroa stream loop 1 hour return / easy The track follows Whareroa Stream through farmland to the rolling sandhills of the northern Inland Track. Along the track you will see a number of native re-vegetation plantings. Turn left onto the northern Inland Track and do the loop walk back to Mackays Crossing via Whareroa Road. Te Ara o Tipapa (wetland walk) 45 minutes return / easy This track runs through the Mackays Crossing wetlands, then crosses low dunes to wetlands that alternate seasonally from dry to wet. Continue to the bush remnant, the only piece of original kahikatea forest remaining on the KƒÅpiti Coast. You can follow a shady track through the remnant or walk on by for good views over the equestrian paddock and the park entrance. Further on you walk through the ‚ÄúMarines‚Äù wetland, first planted in 2003, then past the memorial commemorating the camps that were here during World War II. Coastal Track 1 hour 20 minutes / moderate This walk follows the seaward dunes along the coast between PaekƒÅkƒÅriki and Whareroa Beach, with an entry point at either end. See pingao and spinifex catching and holding the sand on the foreshore while further back muehlenbeckia, shore bindweed and flax protect and strengthen the dune system. A variety of short tracks along the way link with the beach. This is an intermediate mountain bike track with some short, steep sections. If you wish to continue north to Raumati South, you can either use the beach or the Te Ara o Whareroa trail. Find out more at Find Your Wild Inland Track 40 minutes / moderate Th e main section of the Inland Track winds through rolling sand dune ridges between the Memorial lookout in PaekƒÅkƒÅriki and heads north providing stunning views of both Mana and KƒÅpiti Island. It ends at The Coastal Track just before Whareroa Road. Find out more at Find Your Wild Yankee Trail 90 minutes return / easy to moderate Yankee Trail ‚Äì This trail takes you between the two US Marines memorials in Queen Elizabeth Park. Retrace the steps of the US Marines who used this track to walk between Camp Mackay and PaekƒÅkƒÅriki in 1942 and 1943. A sheltered, undulating track that is an easy to intermediate mountain bike ride. Te Ara o Whareroa 2 hours / easy to moderate This is an easy 6km sealed trail that traverses the dune lands of KƒÅpiti Coast, just one hour‚Äôs drive from Wellington. The trail extends from Poplar Avenue in Raumati South all the way through Queen Elizabeth Park to Tilley Road in PaekƒÅkƒÅriki. This popular shared route is used by locals for recreational walking and biking. Find out more at Find Your Wild Dune Swamp Loop 30 minutes/easy to moderate This area has been a long term restoration project by The Friends of QEP and Greater Wellington. Initially the area was planted with pioneer species and now trees such as kahikatea are starting to emerge. The planting has gradually crept year-by[1]year towards the railway line and is slowly helping to form a bush corridor from the coast to Whareroa Farm, and eventually Akatarawa Forest. The walk is a reasonably flat grass track that can be a little bit muddy in the winter. It‚Äôs suitable for most fitness levels, walking and horse riding, but not ideal for buggies. Peatland Ridge Track 30 minutes/easy to moderate The 1.4km walk from Rainbow Court to the Pony Club gate follows gentle undulating terrain that allows you to see the transition from farming to a newly formed native forest. You will walk past regenerating native bush and newly formed natural wetlands as you get near the Old Farm Track. Continue onto the ridge where you will have views over the northern corner of the park where much of the area has being replanted. This replanting was an initiative funded by The Maclean Trust. A peat restoration project is also in the pipeline. Old Farm Track 60 minutes/easy This 3.5km flat, easy walk will take you through previously farmed areas of the park. You will see native regeneration take place over the coming years which is the result of the Recloaking Papat≈´ƒÅnuku project started in 2022. Walk from Poplar Avenue in Raumati South (this entrance is not suitable for parking) all the way to the Mackays Crossing entrance. Peatland Loop 40 minutes/moderate This 2.2km loop is a great place to bring your horse as it's a more remote grass track and not as suitable for cycling. You may see a number of changes in this area over the coming years due to peat restoration projects. KƒÅnuka Track 7 mins/easy This 500m track links from Te Ara o Whareroa Trail into the parts of the park opened in 2022 and conveniently connects with The Old Farm Track and The Peatland Loop. See more Walking and tramping add Mountain biking and cycling The Te Ara o Whareroa trail runs from one end of the park to the other, connecting PaekƒÅkƒÅriki with Raumati South. It's the perfect place for a family bike ride as the track is sealed, making it accessible for all kinds of wheels, and easier for little legs. There are a number of other tracks available to cyclists. While these are not sealed, they aren't necessarily designed for die-hard mountain bikers, and instead would be suited to recreational riders, families and those wanting to take it easy and admire the view. Before you go All tracks are shared with pedestrians and some tracks are also shared with horses, so take care and give way to other users. If you're interested in more challenging routes, across the motorway at Whareroa Farm , you can find a number of tracks that will provide more interesting terrain. Tracks Track Difficulty Whareroa stream loop Easy Coastal Track Intermediate (some short steep sections) Inland Track Intermediate (some short steep sections) Yankee Trail Easy to intermediate Te Ara o Whareroa Easy Peatland Ridge Track Easy to intermediate Old Farm Track Easy KƒÅnuka Track Easy Queen Elizabeth Park trail map Read more here date_range Published 15 Jul 2022 Download now (PDF 753 KB) get_app See more Mountain biking/cycling add Dog walking Dogs are welcome in all parts of the park, except for the Te Ara o Tipapa Loop and Dune Swamp Loop. While dogs are not required to be on a lead, please keep them under control and pick up after them at all times. Queen Elizabeth Park trail map Read more here date_range Published 15 Jul 2022 Download now (PDF 753 KB) get_app See more Dog walking add Horse riding Queen Elizabeth Park is a lovely spot for horse riding, with easy trails over farmland and good access to the beach. There is also plenty of space to park horse floats. Things to think about Follow the parks care code Model aircraft and trams in the park - both can be scary for horses. The jumps at the front of the park are for organised activities only. See the Eventing Wellington website for details. Beach and tracks Horse riding is allowed on multiple tracks in the park. You can also ride in the neighbouring Whareroa Farm where there is a good range of riding tracks. Horses are permitted on all KƒÅpiti beaches with restrictions on beach urban areas during summer . You must ride your horse in a safe and careful manner when on the beach. Keep your horse out of the dunes, as these areas are fragile and contain breeding birds and erosion-control plants. Tracks Details Whareroa Stream Loop 1 hour/4km return. Easy riding. Be aware that this track goes past the model aircraft club area. Inland Track Takes you to PaekƒÅkƒÅriki. Ride the track one way and along the beach on your return. Yankee Trail Loops around the Eventing Wellington area. Dune Swamp loop This is a reasonably flat grass track, taking through restoration areas. Peatland Ridge Track This area provides some great views over the park. Old Farm Track Takes you from Poplar Avenue in Raumati South to the Mackays Crossing entrance. Peatland Loop Flat grass loop in the previously farmed area of the park. KƒÅnuka Track A link track between Te Ara o Whareroa Trail and The Old Farm Track. Queen Elizabeth Park trail map Read more here date_range Published 15 Jul 2022 Download now (PDF 753 KB) get_app Eventing Queen Elizabeth Park is the home to Wellington Eventing - a discipline in horse riding where riders compete across three events (dressage, show jumping and cross country) over a day or more. In each event a rider can earn penalties, and at the end of the three events, the rider with the least penalties wins. Eventing is an area of horse riding that New Zealand has excelled in with numerous Olympic and world championship successes. For more information on Wellington Eventing competitions held at Queen Elizabeth Park see NZ Equestrian . See more Horse riding add Model aeroplane flying Queen Elizabeth Park is home to KƒÅpiti Aeromodellers Club. The club has an airfield accessible from the Mackays Crossing entrance. Spectators are welcome at any time at the club when members are flying. Visitors are asked to park outside the pits area. A suitable spot is signposted to the right of the pits entrance. Find out more and join the club See more Flying model aeroplanes add Volunteering So much of the work done in the regional parks wouldn't be possible without the help of people in our communities. If you want to contribute to the care of Queen Elizabeth Park, you can join one of our community groups. Volunteering in our parks See more Volunteering add History Queen Elizabeth Park and the land it sits on has long attracted people to the area. MƒÅori and European settlement history MƒÅori have been living here for hundreds of years and there were major settlements at Wainui and Whareroa up until the mid-1800s. At the beginning of the 19th century, the KƒÅpiti Coast was occupied by the Muaupoko and Ngati Apa peoples. Over the 19th century there were a number of raids and resulting battles that brought other tribes to the area, including Ngapuhi, Ngati Toa, Ngati Whatua, Waikato and Maniopoto. The land where Queen Elizabeth Park now sits was an important area. The waterways between the sand hills were deep and plentiful, and it was said that canoes could be paddled from PaekƒÅkƒÅriki to Waikanae. From the 1830s onwards, European ships, including whaling boats regularly moored in between KƒÅpiti Island and the coast, as it was a sheltered place to settle. Local MƒÅori gradually left the area and European settlers farmed there. Land was cleared, the wetlands between the sand hills drained and pasture sown. From the 1840s the beach formed part of the main road north, with many travellers stopping overnight at Whareroa. Communication routes improved further and the railway line between Wellington and Foxton was completed in 1886. By the turn of the 20th century, the beach highway was still providing access for the beachfront sections being developed in Raumati and Paraparaumu. The history of this area is rich and complex. For more detailed information, see the QEP Resource Statement (PDF 2.8 MB) . See more Historic add US Marines history Between 1942 and 1944 you would have been forgiven for thinking Queen Elizabeth Park had been taken over by Americans, because we had! During those years over 15,000 American troops were stationed at Queen Elizabeth Park (then Camp Russell), Whareroa Farm (then Camp Mackay) and PaekƒÅkƒÅriki Village (then Camp PaekƒÅkƒÅriki). When World War II broke out in 1939, New Zealand gave total support to Britain and sent our army to the Mediterranean. By 1942, Singapore had fallen and the South Pacific was under threat by Japan. New Zealand agreed to leave its army in North Africa, and so the United States Marines were sent to New Zealand to prepare for the possibility of a Pacific War and protect the country from an invasion. Training tragedy Training took up a lot of the troops' time. The land around the camps was used for live firing exercises, and there were 24km route marches up PaekƒÅkƒÅriki Hill Road (known as "Little Burma Road" to the marines), as well as exercises on the Tararua Ranges. One training activity ended in the deaths of 10 sailors. On June 20, 1943 there was a beach landing training. They were practising for assaults on the Japanese occupied Pacific Islands. Everything seemed to go wrong during this exercise. One boat, named the "beach party" was supposed to be the first onshore and the last to leave the shore during the exercise. Their job was to prepare the beach for the 1,600 marines to follow them. This boat had 25 men on board. During the exercise the tide stranded the boats on the beach, while the weather hit them with freezing cold rain and strong winds and a rising surf. As the last boat off the beach, the beach party didn't leave the shores until after nightfall. When they finally did get to the water their engine woudn't start so a larger boat towed them out stern first (backwards). The waves crashed onto the boat and because the boat was backwards it couldn't ride the waves, instead they hit it and went over it with force. When they were still a good distance from the ship, the boat capsized, throwing the 25 men into the freezing sea. Ten men drowned that night, nine swam ashore and six more were picked up by rescue boats. The WWII U.S. Marines Camp interpretation tells the story of the Marines based at the camp and local residents. We would like to acknowledge The Kapiti US Marines Trust for the work they have done bringing this project to life. You can find this sign via the Wellington Road, PaekƒÅkƒÅriki Entrance to Queen Elizabeth Park, near where Wainui Stream crosses Queen Elizabeth Road. Find the location on Google Maps. To learn more about the history of the Marines stationed in Queen Elizabeth Park, visit Marinesnz.com . See more Historic Description Grab your sneakers, bike or horse - there are tracks here for everyone! Jump on the tram for a ride to the beach or go bird spotting in the wetlands. Find out about the US Marines who trained here in WWII. Learn more about the Trams and Tramway Museum Ramaroa Centre Maclean Trust Project Know before you go Dogs are welcome in all parts of the park, except for the Te Ara o Tipapa Loop. Whilst dogs are not required to be on a lead, please keep them under control and pick up after them at all times. Camp at the PaekƒÅkƒÅriki Holiday Park near the south entrance. Fireworks are banned in all Regional Parks and Forests. Download the park brochure Queen Elizabeth Park brochure Queen Elizabeth Park is the last area of natural dunes on KƒÅpiti‚Äôs coastline. MƒÅori have been living here for hundreds of years and there were major settlements at Wainui and Whareroa‚Ä¶ Read more here date_range Published 15 Jul 2022 Download now (PDF 1.1 MB) get_app Getting there There are three main entrances and each offers a slightly different experience of the park: Mackays Crossing entrance off SH1 PaekƒÅkƒÅriki entrances Raumati South entrances By public transport Train: Catch the Metlink KƒÅpiti Line to the PaekƒÅkƒÅriki railway station, visit the museum in the station and then walk or bike 1.5km to the southern park entrance at the end of Wellington Road. Bus: Take the route 250 bus from Paraparaumu railway station to Jeep Rd (Stop 1470: Jeep Road at the Esplanade or, Stop: 1472 Jeep Road at Forrest Road), Raumati South. Head to Metlink to plan your journey: By bike Plan your route with the KƒÅpiti, Porirua, Tawa cycle map. KƒÅpiti, Porirua and Tawa Cycle Map 2023 | Ko te Mahere Pahikara o KƒÅpiti, o Porirua, o Tawa 2025 Bike network of the Greater Wellington region - Ko ngƒÅ ara Pahikara o P≈çneke Nui Tonu Please Note: Updated Key. The Key now advises users of paths marked as ‚ÄúOff road‚Ä¶ Read more here date_range Published 30 Jan 2023 Download now (PDF 17 MB) get_app By car Mackays Crossing entrance off SH1 The main entrance is near the Ramaroa Centre and the Tramway Museum. Along the road are walking, cycling and horse riding tracks, the WWII US Marines display, restored wetlands and the kahikatea forest remnant. The road continues to Whareroa Beach, surrounding dunes and picnic areas. PaekƒÅkƒÅriki entrances This entrance near the PaekƒÅkƒÅriki Holiday Park gives access to picnic areas, the surf lifesaving club and safe swimming. Turn off SH1 into the PaekƒÅkƒÅriki township and turn right into Wellington Road. The park entrance is at the end of Wellington Road. Access the southern end of the Te Ara o Whareroa trail through the Tilley Road Reserve on Tilley Road. Raumati South entrances Access to walking and cycling tracks including the Te Ara o Whareroa trail, dune systems, and the KƒÅpiti Pony Club. Turn off SH1 at Poplar Ave and follow the road to its end at the Esplanade. Turn left and drive for about 1km to reach the park entrance. Access to the northern end of the Te Ara o Whareroa trail from Matai Road. alarm Updated November 14, 2025 at 10:01 AM Get in touch Phone: 0800496734 Email: info@gw.govt.nz

name: Huka Lodge
homepage_content: Huka Lodge New Zealand | Luxury Taupo Accommodation NZ | 5-Star Resorts By the river at Huka Lodge Long regarded as one of the world‚Äôs most revered and inspirational luxury accommodations, Huka Lodge is set among 17-acres of established, parklike gardens along the banks of the emerald-blue Waikato River near Lake Taup≈ç on New Zealand‚Äôs North Island. With humble beginnings more than a century ago as a fisher‚Äôs camp with white canvas tents pegged along the trout-rich river, Huka Lodge has today secured its place as one of the country‚Äôs oldest and most celebrated luxury lodges. In 2024 Huka Lodge closed for a carefully considered ‚Äòcentenary redesign‚Äô, and reopened its doors in March 2025, ready to welcome a next generation of global luxury traveller. Step inside to experience our luxury Regal luxury Fit for a King: twenty guest suites along with two exclusive owners' residences, the Alan Pye Cottage and Alex van Heeren Cottage, are dotted along the banks of the Waikato River and among verdant gardens, each opening onto rolling green lawns and with the sounds of birdsong and the burbling river as nature's orchestral score. Find your suite Exclusive packages & offers Exclusive packages The century-young Huka Lodge welcomes guests to Taup≈ç in the heart of New Zealand‚Äôs North Island. Specially tailored packages are generously inclusive and allow for extended stays with extra benefits. View all packages and see what‚Äôs included in every stay Classic Huka Stay 3 nights or more with premium extras View Details Baillie Escape A shorter stay with generous inclusions View Details Best Hotels Asia-Pacific 2025 October 2025 The World‚Äôs 50 Best Hotels 2025 The 51-100 List #88 October 2025 Two MICHELIN Keys October 2025 Readers' Choice Awards 2025 #2 World's Best Resort Australasia and the South Pacific October 2025 Readers' Choice Awards 2025 #19 Best Resort Australia and Pacific October 2025 Fodor's Finest 2026: The 5 Best Hotels in Australia and the Pacific September 2025 The WanderSleeps List April 2025 Hotel Awards - Best New Country Retreats April 2025 Star Awards 2025 February 2025 The Best Places to Go in Oceania January 2025 Luxury Awards Asia Pacific - Best Country Lodge in New Zealand June 2024 Oceania‚Äôs Leading Boutique Hotel September 2022 Natural beauty Overlooking the ever-changing Waikato River ‚Äì one moment lazy and deep, the next swirling and icy blue ‚Äì Huka Lodge is located in Taup≈ç, distinguished by its vast lake and endowed with a gentle climate, a leisurely pace and spectacular landscape. Explore Taup≈ç Elegant dining The fine dining and exceptional cuisine on offer at Huka Lodge continues to define the world-class hospitality experience. A vast wine cellar of premium vintages complements a daily-changing menu, showcasing New Zealand‚Äôs finest produce. The restaurant, bar, lounges and terrace offer a traditional lodging ambiance, while signature dining venues are dotted around the estate. Whet your appetite Grand heritage Founded as a fisherman‚Äôs camp in 1924 with white canvas tents pegged by the Waikato River, Huka Lodge was recognised first as a best-kept secret among anglers and grew in popularity with guests from around the world drawn to the property‚Äôs signature checked lawns leading to the river‚Äôs swirling eddies and rushing rapids. A century on, Huka Lodge has a grand heritage, rich in stories and history to be discovered. Discover more Huka Lodge has proudly unlocked Two MICHELIN Keys in The MICHELIN Guide ‚Äì a distinction that recognises the world‚Äôs most exceptional stays, awarded to a lodge that‚Äôs unique in every way. View our listing Huka Lodge has proudly unlocked Two MICHELIN Keys in The MICHELIN Guide ‚Äì a distinction that recognises the world‚Äôs most exceptional stays, awarded to a lodge that‚Äôs unique in every way. View our listing LODGE NEWS AWARDS Tatler Best Awards 2025 Huka Lodge and sister property Longitude 131¬∞ in Australia's Red Centre have been named among Tatler‚Äôs Best 100 Hotels Asia-Pacific, celebrating excellence in hospitality. Discover the full guide to top hotels, restaurants and bars here. READ ARTICLE PRESS Be At One with Nature at this Bucolic Luxury Lodge A year-long, NZ$25 million transformation by Baillie Lodges and Virginia Fisher has revitalised the historic charm Huka Lodge with modern elegance, serene riverscape views and bespoke experiences. Lauren Ho chronicles it here for Wallpaper*. READ ARTICLE PRESS After a multi-million-dollar renovation, Huka Lodge proves why it's New Zealand's best luxury lodge Delicious editor Krysia Bonkowski travelled to Taup≈ç for a first look at the newly reimagined Huka Lodge, where rich heritage meets contemporary elegance in expanded suites, bold interiors, and a new wellness offering set against the lodge‚Äôs iconic riverside backdrop. Read Article PRESS One of New Zealand's Most Impressive Resorts Has 20 Suites Set Along the Country's Longest River Travel + Leisure checked in to the newly refreshed Huka Lodge, where a thoughtful redesign by longtime collaborator Virginia Fisher brings a bold new energy to the riverside retreat, blending nostalgic charm with contemporary flair. Read Article PRESS New Zealand‚Äôs Historic Huka Lodge Reopens With Stunning Expansion Forbes travel writer Laurie Werner journeyed to New Zealand‚Äôs North Island to experience the newly reopened Huka Lodge, where a US$13.5 million renovation has elevated the century-old riverside retreat with expanded suites, floor-to-ceiling views, and a refreshed design by Virginia Fisher. Read Article PRESS A $23m facelift has made NZ‚Äôs most famous holiday lodge even more luxe AFR‚Äôs Ute Junker crossed the ditch to see how a $23 million revamp has taken New Zealand‚Äôs iconic Huka Lodge to new levels of luxury, with refreshed interiors, fine dining flair, and signature riverside charm. Read Article PRESS T&C Hotel Awards 2025 ‚Äì Best New Rural Country Retreats Huka Lodge has been named in Town & Country's 12 Best New Rural Country Retreats list - a prestigious collection of top-tier rural getaways, from New Zealand to Norway and Bavaria to Britain, serenity is guaranteed. Read Article PRESS New Zealand‚Äôs original luxury lodge reopens after a $22 million renovation Gourmet Traveller‚Äôs Michael Harry offers a personal take on the newly reopened Huka Lodge, highlighting its $22.6 million refurbishment by Baillie Lodges. With refreshed interiors, a serene wellness retreat and elevated dining, the iconic hideaway balances heritage charm with a new era of quiet, contemporary luxury. Read Article PRESS Centenary Revamp Revealed Traveller‚Äôs Trudi Jenkins offers a personal review of the newly reopened Huka Lodge, commenting: ‚ÄòAt first glance, the remote setting and quiet luxury conjure an episode of Succession - Tom and Shiv strolling over the manicured lawns... But there is a more layered history to Huka that speaks to a genuine desire to protect its unique charm‚Äô. READ ARTICLE PRESS The Best Places to Go in Australia, New Zealand and the South Pacific in 2025 Cond√© Nast Traveller UK has cast the net wide in considering the ‚ÄòBest Places to Go in Australia, New Zealand and the South Pacific in 2025‚Äô, naming Huka Lodge‚Äôs hometown of Taup≈ç in the celebrated list. Read Article PRESS Riverside Retreat Luxury Travel magazine‚Äôs Belinda Craigie travelled to Huka Lodge and reports back that, 'A stay at Huka Lodge is just the remedy for leaving stresses behind and enjoying the finer features of Aotearoa - nature, exceptional food and wine, and genuine hospitality.' We agree! Read Article PRESS Seven Best Hotels Huka Lodge has been named in Fodor‚Äôs prestigious World‚Äôs Best Hotels list for the Asia Pacific region. As writer Michelle Tchea says, 'Known as the 'Grande Dame of New Zealand', Huka Lodge started as a simple fishing lodge in the 1920s and has grown into the premier location for luxury experiences.' Read Article PRESS Weekend in Taupo Writer Sue Hoffart takes a long weekend in TaupoÃÑ, with Huka Lodge as her luxury base. 'Run, don‚Äôt walk from end-of-week commitments to reach Huka Lodge before the sun‚Äôs last rays bounce off this riverside beauty spot,' she says. Read Sue‚Äôs top 12 things to in the region as seen in Air New Zealand‚Äôs inflight magazine Kia Ora. Read Article PRESS Celebrating in Style Celebrating her 30th birthday at Huka Lodge, travel writer and global wanderer Brooke Saward of World of Wanderlust writes ‚ÄòI was starting to devise a plan to stay for good‚Äô, so taken was she with her experience. Read the full feature here. READ ARTICLE PRESS Loved by Locals Kiwis' are known for being house proud, and with great reason. With two years of lockdowns and border closures seeing a rise in domestic travel, Amy Louise Bailey for Travel + Leisure writes about the home-grown destinations locals can't get enough of. READ ARTICLE PRESS Romance Rating Big 7 Travel has named Huka Lodge as the sixth most romantic hotel in the world and number one in New Zealand. With suites layered in luxury, secluded dining nooks and mesmerising river views, it's easy for hearts to be sent aflutter here. READ ARTICLE PRESS NZ Best Bucket List Travel Experiences New Zealand Herald‚Äôs travel section has wrapped up the bucket list for 2022 ‚Äì for travel to wherever we can ‚Äì including Aotearoa‚Äôs world renowned Huka Lodge. We think it‚Äôs a top to-do too! Read all about it here. READ ARTICLE JOURNAL In Profile: Kerry Molloy Born and raised in New Zealand, Huka Lodge General Manager Kerry Molloy continues to lead the award-winning lodge in 2021 and beyond. Take a moment to read about his connection to New Zealand‚Äôs oldest luxury lodge. READ FEATURE NEWS Founder Alex van Heeren Honoured Huka Lodge founder Alex van Heeren is celebrated for his vision to create a superlative hospitality experience - the first of its kind in New Zealand. At Baillie Lodges we have honoured his legacy by renaming the Owner‚Äôs Cottage as the Alex van Heeren Cottage. VIEW COTTAGE With a reputation for peerless fly fishing and generous hospitality, Huka Lodge combines class, discretion and impeccable service in one of the most serene locations on the planet. John Barker Escape Huka Lodge has legendary status in New Zealand, it is spoken about in revered tones. On arrival, I realised there may be more to this place than a fancy room and breath-taking views. Kelli Brett Cuisine I cannot readily articulate just how the property held me in its grasp at first sight. However, it did, and still does to this day. Was it the sheer force and power of the turquoise green waters of the Waikato River on the one hand and all that tranquility and softness on the other? Perhaps it was simply the contradiction of the two. Alex van Heeren Founder, Huka Lodge There are so many things to like: the riverfront setting; the lavish duplex accommodations; and the superb cuisine. It is one of the finest hideaways of its type in the world. Andrew Harper Andrew Harper Travel Follow us FOR RESERVATION ENQUIRIES CALL +64 7 222 4555 OR ENQUIRE HERE reservations@hukalodge.co.nz +64 7 222 4555 ‚úï Want to be the first to know? name: Asure Kapiti Court Motel
homepage_content: ASURE Kapiti Court Motel | Paraparaumu Accommodation | Book Direct and Save Check Availability / Book Online Welcome to ASURE Kapiti Court Motel Paraparaumu Accommodation NZ ASURE Kapiti Court Motel enjoys the best of all worlds. Ideal for those wanting a quiet, sunny break within walking distance of good shopping, restaurants, and an expansive beach with views of Kapiti Island . Ideal for those who want to experience the challenge of the internationally acclaimed Paraparaumu Beach Links Course that is immediately opposite. At the end of the day relax and enjoy a leisurely swim in the pool or enjoy a leisurely walk along the beach and the stunning sunsets. Whatever your interests, we aim to provide you with an enjoyable and memorable stay on the Kapiti Coast in Paraparaumu. We look forward to welcoming you to the ASURE Kapiti Court Motel . Rooms Location Facilities Local Activities Motel Facilities Heated swimming pool BBQ area and playground Offstreet parking and more! 64 SKY TV channels Read our guest reviews Great Location Walking distance to the waterfront and beach. Spacious room close to the pool. Ideal on a sunny warm day. Staff friendly and welcoming. Pat Paraparaumu Stopover We stopped here on our way up to Auckland, it was very convenient and at a reasonable price. The owner was exceedingly helpful and friendly, the room was large with a kitchen and eating area. I found the bed to be very comfortable. I would recommend this place to any overnight traveller. Marco PARAPARAUMU BEACH WEATHER ASURE Kapiti Court Motel NZ Freephone: 0800 52 66 83 Email: info@kapiticourtmotel.co.nz 341 Kapiti Road, Paraparaumu Beach, Paraparaumu 5032, Kapiti Coast ASURE Accommodation Group members accept all major credit cards and Farmlands, Q Card, Ruralco, Fonterra Farm Source and Farmers Card. ¬© 2025 - Sitemap - Admin Login - Website by GuestTraction

homepage_content: Asian Fusion Auckland | Thai Restaurant Auckland | Kiss Kiss Eatery Asian fusion restaurant Inspired by the street food culture of Thailand. Great for large groups, families or dates nights. Order Online Book a table We are Kiss Kiss, a family of eaters, drinkers and good timers. We pride ourselves on delivering a unique hospitality experience without an attitude. We are proud members of the Balmoral community situated among the hustle and bustle of Dominion Road. We throw a whole lot of love into what we do and that is something we hope you feel when you spend time with us. Check this out! Restaurant Menu Mon 5pm ‚Äì 9pm Tues 5pm ‚Äì 9pm Wed 5pm ‚Äì 9pm Thurs 11am ‚Äì 2.30pm 5pm ‚Äì 9.00pm Frid 11am ‚Äì 2.30pm 5pm ‚Äì 9:30pm Sat 12pm ‚Äì 9.30pm Sun 12pm ‚Äì 9pm Catering 10% off all catering Order online Bookings Vouchers Testimonials David Ballouz Amazing and delectable take on south east asian cuisine! The ribs are one of the best I have ever had and the noodles were awesome. Spice level were perfect! Great ambiance and staff were great to talk to and really seemed to be enjoying their work! Wasim Akram Tried bang bang beef noodles, nibbles, mango rice pudding for dessert. It was amazing. Definitely the best place right now in Auckland. Must try. Thanks team kisskiss for mouthwatering food and great service. Emil Hinchliff Wow the service in this place is amazing! Had a lovely young man called Luka serve me and my party ‚Äì really friendly and made sure we were all cared for. Food was good, but the service made the experience exceptional. Would recommend this restaurant to all my friends ‚Äì we will be sure to visit again soon! Coogie Bear The last couple of times we‚Äôve been there, food has been delicious and service very efficient. Reasonable pricing too. We feel they went through a period where their food was a bit average, but they‚Äôve definitely upped their game. Paul Garcia Always busy, may it be a weekend or the middle of the week. It just shows how beloved this Thai restaurant is. The food is always great. I would always order the pork ribs and the pork bao buns. Try it, and you‚Äôll never regret it. It has lots of seating, and the music isn‚Äôt too loud, which I always appreciate. Craig Lancaster Something different. Food was definitely tasty. Loved the vegetables and the rice in particular. Staff were friendly. Decor was eclectic. Sammy Iqbal Absolutely gem of a place. I didn‚Äôt know it existed until I came upon it by chance while looking for a car park. Amazing food. Tasty, good portion size. The sticky chicken wings are very good. Nice balance of flavour. Michael Jerome de Loyola I‚Äôve been here twice already. The first time, we had the ribs and pad thai. They were so delicious. Second time, we had the green curry and pork belly with rice, they were delicious as well. Then restaurant have the asian vibe that reminded me of a carinderia (street style restaurant) back home in the Philippines. Get instant 10% off when you place feedback! homepage_content: Shelby Motor Lodge - Invercargill 295 Tay Street, Invercargill 03 211 1295 or 0800 295 295 shelbymotorlodge@gmail.com Check Availability / Book Online Check Availability / Book Online Welcome to Shelby Motor Lodge - Invercargill Looking for quality Accommodation in Invercargill, then you need to stay at the Shelby Motor Lodge. Shelby Motor Lodge presents to you the best accommodation in Invercargill. Our Modern Motel complex offers you, quiet luxury accommodation in spacious, apartment style rooms with modern d√©cor, ideal for Business, sports and pleasure. Our Invercargill Motel will meet all your requirements with our warm, comfortable, clean, affordable, units, complete with kitchenette, Netflix, including high speed, wifi internet. Book Directly with us for the Best Price. High speed wifi internet Netflix Fully equipped kitchens Room types View all rooms Services and Facilities View all Location Things to see Read Guest Reviews "Great place to stay. Modern, comfortable, well-equipped and close to everything. Staff all really friendly and happy to help. Good parking and room has everything you may need whether you're just passing through or staying a few nights. Recommended." - John "Excellent motel we stayed as a family of 5 and the room was epic! Highly recommend for families and plenty of space, warm, clean and just superb! Hosts friendly and seamless check in process. Only wished we‚Äôd stayed another night! Thanks for a wonderful stay. Thank you" - Kiwinz "Comfortable for one night stay. Stayed on way south. Warm and comfortable. Friendly staff. Stayed in a, studio unit which had everything we needed. Location is just out of town but convenient. Just down from burger King which was handy as we arrived later." - Matty "Our accommodation was in one of the adjoining houses - which was very well specced! Very modern and clean and spacious - it was like having a huge house to ourselves. Location also very convenient. Staff were super helpful too, allowing us to store some gear with them for a few days while we visited Stewart Island (we returned and stayed another day following our return to Invercargill)." - Ben B "We stayed in a unit at the back of the motel complex. King size comfy bed, separate lounge/kitchen, all the amenities you could need like a dishwasher, washer/dryer combination. Very quiet and very clean. Shout out to Issie who was warm and welcoming and made our stay a pleasure. Many thanks!!!" - Julie C Read Guest Reviews Phone: 03 211 1295 / 0800 295 295 - Email: shelbymotorlodge@gmail.com Address - 295 Tay Street, Invercargill ¬© 2025 - Admin Login - Sitemap - Website by GuestTraction

homepage_content: Souvla Greek Street Food | Queenstown, NZ top of page Food of the people, for the people. Experience a world of new flavours. name: The Runholder
homepage_content: The Runholder 0 WINE DINE GIN Martinborough‚Äôs finest under one roof The Runholder is home to Te Kairanga, Martinborough Vineyard & Lighthouse Gin. With our Restaurant, Tasting Room, Cellar Door and Gin Distillery overlooking Martinborough‚Äôs rolling hills and vineyards, The Runholder is the place to enjoy Wairarapa‚Äôs exquisite food, fine wines and original gin. About Feast on charcoal-grilled seafood, prime cuts and shared plates from our √† la carte menu for lunch or dinner. Our menu celebrates Wairarapa‚Äôs local produce and perfectly complements our wines and gin. Taste iconic wines from Te Kairanga and Martinborough Vineyard wineries with a wine tasting flight, or share an aged bottle from the cellar. Relax with Lighthouse Gin cocktails and watch distiller Rachel Hall craft her next batch. Before you head home, choose a bottle or two from the cellar door to take with you. The Runholder welcomes you to Martinborough. Visit Us Make a booking Visit Us Buy a Gift Card

name: iTi
homepage_content: Iti - a drinks & bites garden | Titirangi food and drink | 421 Titirangi Road, Titirangi, Auckland, New Zealand top of page We are iTi. A drinks & bites garden in the soul of Titirangi. If you‚Äôre into native bush, craft beer on tap, the best cocktails & wine, you‚Äôll find yourself at home around here. Saturday & Sunday music every week to feed your soul! Cheers to that! See Menu Book Now The Lewisham Awards 2024 Outstanding Local Establishment - West iTi has won the Lewisham Award for Outstanding Local Establishment‚ÄîWest. A big thank you to everyone who voted for us and to our amazing team, who work hard every day to make your visit with us so enjoyable. Named after Richard Lewisham, a pioneer of the Auckland Hospitality Scene, The Lewisham Awards were established in 2002 with the main objective of encouraging excellence in the city's hospitality community. With this in mind, the best in the business are nominated and honoured by their peers once a year, followed by an after-party to celebrate their success. Find out more Estrella Damm Top 50 New Zealand Gastropubs We were thrilled that ITI Drinks & Bites Garden, was named a finalist for these prestigious New Zealand Awards. At ITI, we strive to create a welcoming atmosphere where people can indulge in innovative dishes made from locally sourced ingredients, paired with a curated selection of beverages showcasing the best Kiwi hospitality. We were thrilled to be included on this list alongside such a fantastic group of gastropubs. Thanks also to our loyal customers and community for their ongoing support and for voting us into the finalist category. Find out more bottom of page

We‚Äôre within walking distance of the Vodafone Events Centre and Vector Wero Whitewater Park, as well as minutes from Rainbow‚Äôs End theme park and Auckland Botanic Gardens. Go shopping at Westfield Manukau City, hit the greens of Wattle Downs Golf Course, or head into the heart of Auckland, 23 kilometers away. Back at our non-smoking hotel, make the most of a gym, caf√©, and free WiFi. All the Right Amenities You'll love our fitness center Our contemporary hotel has everything you need for a relaxing stay. Grab breakfast, lunch, or a tasty snack at our on-site caf√©, or kick back and order room service. Stay active in our well-equipped fitness center, use free high-speed WiFi to plan the day, and host your next event in our meeting space. You can also take advantage of paid parking. Each comfortable, non-smoking guest room is thoughtfully appointed with a flat-screen HDTV with cable, a kitchenette with mini-refrigerator and coffee maker, ironing amenities, and hair dryer. Explore the Auckland Area Ride a coaster, discover outdoor beauty, or visit museums Tackle two rafting courses at the Vector Wero Whitewater Park or ride the epic Corkscrew Coaster at Rainbow‚Äôs End. Check out the collection of exotic palms at the Auckland Botanic Gardens, see salt water crocodiles at Butterfly Creek Zoo, or enjoy a hike and picnic at Totara Park. Venture into Auckland‚Äôs city center for attractions like the Sky Tower, Auckland War Memorial Museum, and Waitemata Harbour. If you‚Äôre feeling adventurous, take the ferry to Rangitoto Island to explore the stunning volcanic cone and the impressive pohutukawa forest. name: Rona Bay Beach
homepage_content: Rona Bay at Wharf - Swim Guide Support Swim Guide Today Rona Bay at Wharf Lower Hutt, Wellington Managed by: The Swim Guide - New Zealand Share: Donate today to help us keep the data flowing Current Water Quality No data available This status is based on the latest sample. The Swim Guide - New Zealand updates the status of this beach as soon as test results become available. Monitoring Frequency: Rona Bay at Wharf is sampled Weekly from November 1st to March 31st. Water Quality Graph: Pie Chart Bar Chart Interval: Yearly Quarterly Monthly About Rona Bay at Wharf Rona Bay is a sand and pebble beach situated in Eastbourne. The beach features sand hills and verges a large park. With changing facilities, a pool, toilets, a playground and plenty of parking this site is a great place for families. This site is monitored as a part of Greater Wellington Regional Council‚Äôs Recreational Water Quality Monitoring Programme, which is specifically designed to inform the public about the suitability of various sites across the region for swimming and other recreational activities. Source Information The Greater Wellington Regional Council monitors water quality at popular swimming beaches throughout the Wellington region. Water quality data on Swim Guide is sourced from the LAWA Can I Swim Here? website. www.lawa.org.nz/swim At this site, the level of Enterococci is determined using predictive modelling year round. Enteroccoci is a faecal indicator bacteria used to indicate the level of harmful pathogens in the water. See information on recreational water quality monitoring in New Zealand in this LAWA factsheet: https://www.lawa.org.nz/learn/factsheets/coastal-and-freshwater-recreation-monitoring/ Beach sites are shown as a GREEN swim icon if the latest Enterococci predicted result was within the guidelines (0 - 280 Enterococci / 100 mL). Beach sites are shown as a RED swim icon if the latest predicted result exceeded standards (280 Enterococci / 100 mL) or is known to frequently exceed the standards or there is a temporary water quality issue outside the routine testing programme (e.g. sewage overflow). See information on the standards for recreational water quality monitoring in New Zealand in the 'What do the swim icons mean?' LAWA factsheet. LAWA recommends for all sites, to avoid swimming for 2 - 3 days after significant rain, even for sites that normally have good water quality. A good rule of thumb is to check that you can see your toes in knee deep water. See www.lawa.org.nz/swim for up to date information on current warnings and alerts, weather conditions, tides, real-time water temperatures, what facilities are available, the monitoring history at this site and helpful factsheets. Beaches Near This One SEE All
